EF2d1jIKh6o-ER9sIrYepg.text: Beautiful location, in a giant converted warehouse with elegant steel pillars and open brickwork everywhere, next to Granary Square, just north of King's Cross and St Pancras and across the canal - is it Regent's Canal? Its going to be excellent area, with some great trees and a good vibe despite the construction around giving hints of brave new world of N London. We went late at night Friday and really enjoyed the wine and a great tasting pizza, also enjoyed the friendly helpful staff and buzzing atmosphere. The back of Caravan is full of sacks of coffee, too late at night to try the coffee so will have to be back.

QJw4lUUeKDYvOgXUNJqM6Q.text: The food was really good. The cornbread with chipotle butter was awesome. The chicken breast with adobo was very good although I added salt and pepper to mine... It didn't have enough of a punch til I added the s&p but after it was super good. The champagne with absinthe infused berries was good, the tofu and green beans had a nice sauce. The Dante's reserve was really sweet... Too sweet, the white negroni was too bitter for my taste. The service started fine but the wait staff changed and our second server ignored us for about 30 min at a time until the host came up and asked us if we needed anything at which point we mentioned that we'd been waiting for drinks for a while. He gave them to us on the house so that was nice.

h5Wvv0tBkDCId5kl6wg7YA.text: The most memorable drink ever, an Earl Grey Gimlet cocktail! It was absolutely delicious and it was like nothing I had ever tasted before.  We enjoyed a number of tapas plates. The avocado bread was memorable and fresh.  I loved the trendy and beautiful clientele and gorgeous space. I loved the exterior facing a wonderful water fountain feature!

gvrpkYHvmzr8SOm7MyZOFA.text: If you can fall in love with a restaurant than I fell in love with Caravan. Ok. fine. FINE. I fell in love with the handsome hipster baristas, high ceilings, exposed brickwork and delectable pastries. How have I never been here? It's like the Mothership. Basically this place is a middle class yuppie paradise. Hip, young things swigging coffee, talking about their polenta brunch choice and spending £4.50 on an orange juice. Yes, we waited. We waited over half an hour, but it was brunch so what's the rush? We ordered a sweet muffin, which was kinda of like a cupcake-muffin, with frosting. Sourdough toast with avocado and sausage and a chorizo bake. Everything was good but next time I definitely want to try the waffles! I didn't find it over priced but maybe if I come back for dinner (yes, obviously I will) then I can try their small plates.

-g1jAwYsyGJu9SqBxyOXEA.text: I'm trying to kick a bad habit of Instagramming all of my food, and goddammit Caravan, you got me to relapse.In my silly optimism one Sunday morning I forgot to make reservations, so my friend and I showed up and were informed that there would be a 45 minute wait. No problem, we'll just go frolic in the fountains... wait, 24 year old women don't do that. We'll just go for a quick walk through the university bulidings and climb the viewing platform and do other things that adults do.. barely 15 minutes later, I got a text from Caravan informing us that our table was ready. Huzzah!I have a personal rule that if there's ever pork belly on a menu, no matter what the circumstances, I order the pork belly. Always. No exceptions. Turns out there's pork belly on this menu, with a kimchi pancake and a runny egg. And some creamy barbecue sauce and watercress garnish. Oh. My. Screw you, Caravan, for making the Asian chick start photographing her food again. Screw you and your beautiful, delicious brunch. You were everything my hangover was not.

0Dx7_Ik6v1zL5ses_PKD6A.text: I was so disappointed in this because I'd read such great things about it.I went here last weekend with 2 girlfriend to have Sunday brunch. The sort of Sunday brunch where you talk for hours and generally set the world to right (only girls will understand how important it is to have these sessions. They should be mandatory).As you can't book a table, we put our names down and were told it would be a half hour wait. We came back half an hour later to find that we still couldn't be seated, and it was closer to the hour mark before we were. The place was packed. Absolutely rammed. We got started with some hair of the dog cocktails (again, mandatory) and browsed through the menus while discussing flower pressing and kittens and all other miscellanea that us ladies enjoy doing.I had informed the waiter when we sat down that I'm gluten-free, and he just said 'okay'. This proved to be an issue when we came to order as it turned out I had not been given the right menu - I had to be given another one and our order was subsequently delayed from being taken. Not great when you're starving hungry.The main issue with this place is the service. The waiters/waitresses were friendly enough, but they didn't seem to be assigned to a particular area - they all just kind of floated about at random, which meant that orders got confused and delayed. My friend asked for a side with her meal which arrived 10 minutes after the rest of the meal as the waiters kept forgetting it.The meal itself was okay. I had some sort of smoked salmon thing, which was nice but not very substantial. I was still hungry afterwards, as was one of my friends who had ordered the same as me. The other ordered some sort of Kimchi thingy, which she said was brilliant. I should have ordered something else, although I was limited due to my aforementioned, ridiculously annoying dietary requirements.For me, the real issue came when we asked for the dessert menu. It took us ages to flag down a waiter (one of us had to get up to grab one, in the end) and the lady nodded and walked off. She came back, chucked the bill down on the table and strode off. We were pretty annoyed by this as we had asked for the dessert menu, not the bill, and the attitude was just unwarranted.We decided to just pay the bill and leave. Another waitress came back over to sort us out, and we told her that we wanted the service charge taken off. We also explained what had just happened with the other waitress - she was mortified and brought us over some free desserts. Very nice of her, even though it wasn't her fault.On the whole, it's a really nice, funky place, and I'm sure when it's a bit quieter it provides a much better experience. That Sunday, however, was not one of those times. I won't be in a rush to go back, although I might give the other branch a try next time us ladies reconvene.

g17v_Zlw18QX-gR8mmGTIQ.text: One of my favourite breakfast places in London.The walk there is amazing, up past the being constructed buildings at Kings Cross, over the bridge, through the fountains, into a converted building which once held Lincolnshire wheat for London's bakers. Check out the interactive display table which shows the history of the surrounding area.Into the open plan restaurant - great bar, wonderful pizzas, original breakfasts, coffee beans roasted onsite.Fav item to order is the baked eggs, with tomato / pepper ragout, yoghurt, and add chorizo.

5cxhhDqJrEhs8BgoHdP45A.text: I was pleasantly surprised by this place. Essentially as a lost tourist with a token Brit new to the city, we found this place after walking far too long along that stream/river/thing. We needed beer and sustinance. Ok I needed beer, he got tea and a snack. Normally I wouldn't bother writing a review for a meal that small, but I enjoyed the service, atmosphere and food so much that I'm giving these guys one. Maybe it's because when I was in university the food options were crap, but honestly it was a great place to eat in.The service was friendly and very attentive. Their locally brewed beer was tasty, the tea was lovely and their cookie was delicious. The atmosphere is really friendly, easy-going but still quite clean and crisp. It can be hard to find a new place that's inviting but still modern. I would definitely go back here for a proper meal!

2RWl6c15PRf5sA3rmioENA.text: Jalapeno cornbread with chipotle butter. TO DIE FOR.I thought about ordering several more plates of the cornbread and making Jalapeno cornbread my entire meal but I thought my stomach might hate me afterward.Also luckily we were able to try the other items on the menu:Chorizo and sweet potato croquettes, saffron aioli (£5) was one of my favorites. Three croquettes with a crispy exterior and fiery interior.Grilled quail, creamed sweetcorn, maple bacon (£6.5) was a bit hard to eat, since it was a bit small, but still nicely grilled.Wish I could remember what the other dishes were but it was really nice to sit outside and soak the last of the summer days in.

NDs_2OBBDEttwjQseXcxEQ.text: Hipster ground zero in London with good food too. -converted warehouse-lots of reused wood-coffee roasters in house serving third wave coffee-cute hipster serversWe went there for a group dinner so there was no wait and there was a set menu to pick from. Everything we ate was good although the starters were the most creative and tasty.They seem to get inspiration from all over the culinary world, some Mexican and Southern Comfort food, Japanese and Italian. Everything was pretty tasty.We started with olives and curried nuts as well as jamon, finochiona, nduja and caperberries. Both were get starts to the meal and the nduja had just the right texture.We then had small plates to share: 1. a Quinoa and squash dish that served with med flavours with feta and peppers. It was very satisfying vegetarian dish.2. Spiced cauliflower, the charred cauliflower was nicely dressed with harissa and yoghurt3.Pan fried mackerel, an interesting dish with nori puree and diakon remoulade4. Crispy fried chicken with jerk mayo, the chicken wasn't that crispyThen we could choose a main course, our table tried all of them.  we had:1. orange teriyaki udon noodles-a bit too sweet2. Ancho pork fillet, nogada sauce-pork was cooked nicely3. Confit duck leg, cossoulet, the beans were undercooked but the confit duck was cooked perfectly4.mozzerella pizza-all the pizza are traditional thin crust made simply and well5.spinach, goat cheese and articoke pizza6. ham and tomato pizzaDessert:1.Affogato- they roast and grind their espresso in house and it shows2. Chocolate cheesecake-the almond ice cream and salted almonds were a nice balance to the creamy sweet cheesecake3.peanut butter parfait, a play on peanut butter and jelly that works.With such a large group there was a long delay between the starters and the main course but the service was some of the best we had in London with servers who actually checked in periodically to see if we needed more food or water, a rare thing in London.It's a very noisy space and the tables are close together. The atmosphere is London hipster. The place is wheelchair accessible as was the bathrooms but the narrow space between table could be a challenge.

KYJtNvm0_0TjAzMFR5nedQ.text: Very late lunch at caravan and the food was so good, fusion combinations from many cuisines, a lot of Asian influence. I really liked the tomato focaccia bread and balsamic butter. For starters the coconut lime chicken salad was light and refreshing. The soft shell crab really surprised me as it was not the usual from elsewhere, with an Indian influence. The smoked salmon dish should have just used raw salmon as the sauce made the dish too salty. Really loved the seared trout main, with strong and inventive Japanese flavours. One of the best fish dishes In my memory. And the crumble to end was divine.

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Crumble
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Seared trout
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Soft shell crab

PFbnosD7Zt4UNH4LCZdRyQ.text: I love the area and love the food.I went for lunch recently and it was a surprisingly nice day.I ordered the 4 cheeses pizza with artichokes and oh.my.god.I got it all over me but it was so worth it!Service was also really good and the decor is lovely.Only thing is that the acoustics are awful!But maybe it was just a really noisy day?Well worth a visit in any case.

r6goxzZdR8l9HeGRWWxlfw.text: This review is really just for the bar as I've not eaten in the restaurant part.Not the fastest service and lacking severely in non-beer or soft drink options for those of us who aren't much into beer. But all in our group found a beer or two that they quite liked on offer. I wasn't offered a cup or ice for my Diet Coke. Just the can. :(On a humorous point, 2 of our friends declared the toilet facilities a bit "too Ally McBeal." They're unisex. One bathroom with 1/2 denoted stalls for men and 1/2 for women. I don't have a problem with this - in fact none of the women in our group did. But nearly all the dudes were weirded out by it. (Guys are weird sometimes).I hear very good things about their brunch, so I'd love to head back not just for drinks!

rcUQxp2t3DaMQacTJ3YrYw.text: This place is only going to get better by association now the area is filling up with great places to eat, drink & shop.I've only visited this Caravan on sunny days. My visits have been sporadic but I've always left impressed. Whether it's a quick macchiato at the bar, a cold beer looking out over Granary Square or a tapas selection with friends Caravan have always provided good quality ingredients, knowledgeable & friendly staff and tasty fare.I recommend to all! Tip: ask them what drinks to recommend, they always get it right.

SzyYl9zRv6n4nVSpM1HxsQ.text: I was excited to try Caravan Kings Cross having been to the Exmouth Market branch several times. The building itself is really impressive and they have a great system in place to handle the constant queues where you are seated at the coffee/smoothie bar at the back while you wait for your table.What I didn't like about Caravan was the service. Our sever didn't mention the specials and our brunch arrived seconds after placing our order. This made me feel as if I was in a canteen being served slops and not paying top dollar for a flashy breakfast which I would expect to be made to order. Food was ok but not great and really didn't appreciate the gratuity being automatically added to our bill as we weren't happy with the service.

wmYSjoy90lIc0QVekx8BkA.text: This would be a 5 star review if it wasn't for the fact that Caravan Exmouth Market is smaller, and in my opinion better.I believe Caravan to have one of the best brunch menus in London. It is perfect for a morning-after-the-night-before late brekkie and pint! Plus their coffee roasting heritage and knowledge means you get a mean caffeinated beverage here too.Try the jalapeño corn bread with fried egg and black beans - delicious - but also give the Exmouth branch a look if you want more light, less people and more personal service.

u9zwsiq6IEgpXZEGwXhRVw.text: Great brunch spot and worth the wait! Some of the portion sizes leave things to be desired at times.

0MoBGVEGxy4OxvVU4AK4uA.text: This trendy restaurant has a nice atmosphere and decor but frankly it is a rip - off giving very poor value.  I paid £9 for a lunch dish that was a special of the day. I expected a main course but was served a small snack appropriate to a starter on a restaurant  menu.   Most disappointing. The snack was OK and the service was passable but I had to go to a supermarket  nearby to get more food!

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom

6O0dAs6HO-I1bhR2u67wYg.text: # Super spot for Sunday brunchI came here on an autumnal yet mild and sunny Sunday with friends in hopes to grab a table for our weekend brunch. Considering they do not take table bookings for brunch on weekends shows their popularity and confidence in attracting walk-in diners wishing to fill their stomachs with epic food. On queuing we were informed there would be an hour or more wait but the receptionist would notify our table of four as available via a callback through the phone. It was roughly about an hour's wait whilst we ventured to the neighbouring Grain Store (another great brunch place) and sat down for a tipple.On returning a call, we headed back and were shown to our alfresco seating, and luckily with the warm weather was a great place to breathe in fresh air and feel closer to the bustling market crowd at Granary Sq. We ordered four different breakfasts between us and the food quality was exceptional. Matching the smooth aroma of my cup of long black coffee, the taste of my Caravan Fry was as fresh as homemade farmhouse food, my only niggle was that they were so busy they ran out of field mushrooms. Still, this setback didn't ruin my experience and I would definitely come back here again.

KKI_VF_VsnYeRCqmS1yIFg.text: We're lucky enough to have in our friends some real Londoners who know where to find the great places :-)So on a Sunday we find our way to King's Cross... just follow the crowd, we were not the only ones to wait for the opening of Caravan ;-)So you find yourself in front of this old fully renovated building, shared with the university of Arts. I guess in the summer you can use the great huge terrace, but for now it was inside. The decoration is great, a mix between old and new, a bit rough and industrial but still very cosy.For the food and coffee. Great coffee, and delicious food. Eggs or salads, or more sweet treats, it was all delicious. And I would advice going to see what they have as tarts, muffins, etc... For the service, very friendly and efficient (they'd better be, it's quite a big place)What was also nice, maybe for a next time in a smaller group, is to join the big tables they have.

2vwzWSCBBDuIOK1RZtKIEw.text: The best breakfast i had in the city. I will eat here every time I come to London. The scone was unlike anything I have ever eaten. Loved it!

Ioac-dbM6gDcm9gjLBvVAQ.text: Great Flat Whites, cornbread is to die for ;) The patio is lots of fun on a sunny day.The service was attentive and food came out quickly.

K7GnQ7cVHnvD8jYpi5FVDg.text: It was a beautiful day so we chose (along with pretty much everyone else who was there) to grab a table outside in the sunshine. It had a really nice buzz with everyone chatting excitedly and the sounds of the children playing in the nearby fountains. They also had these really cute, cosy blankets for people in case it got cold. We ordered some peach bellinis - because brunch - and perused the menu. I fully intended to be original but I'm sorry I just can't help it, when I see a mention of avocado I just have to have it and so poached eggs on toast with a side of avocado were swiftly ordered by myself while Victoria went for the caravan fry with scrambled eggs.I won't lie the service was  pretty slow due to the fact that they were so busy but after our order had finally been taken the food arrived in no time at all and was quickly scoffed. My biggest gripe was that there was only a single solitary piece of toast which really wasn't enough to go around and especially not for the price I paid but the eggs were cooked to perfection and the avocado with its chilli kick was fantastic smooshed into the sourdough bread.

osmOS9nz_pb9j502pNJfSA.text: Excellent service and a wonderful menu at Caravan. The tea is freshly made, and the ingredients are used with a twist on British tradition. I came twice for breakfast and had different items each time: the baked eggs and the classic breakfast with bacon and mushroom. Both were excellent choices. My colleagues sampled the pancakes with berries and marscapone cheese, the avocado toast, and the jalapeño cornbread and all were wonderful.

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom

-Srj2_4f-m2cC_9PFRJrdg.text: Five of us arrived on a Saturday evening without booking, hoping for an outside table as it was such lovely weather. There were only outside bar seats available and the promise of a table within 30 minutes. Luckily we were almost immediately moved to a table. The experience was generally good (fast seating, fantastic food, helpful wait-staff) although I it could be a little more speedy and friendly over all. We had a series of small plates and pizza's to share between us with cocktails. The beef carpaccio, burrata and margherita pizza were particularly memorable.I had one of the most amazing cocktails - I think it was the chef's special. It had popcorn in a teabag and was one of the most delicately, yet multidimensional flavoured cocktails I have ever had. Amazing! Sadly it wasn't the first of the evening so I can no longer remember the name!  This was my second visit and I will return again as it is in such a great location both for people watching when Granary Square is busy and being so close to King's Cross Station. The quality of the food makes this place good value for money.

1iuqm0eqGQftTQMNSPcb8Q.text: I finally had a chance to visit Caravan Kings Cross last weekend. I was very excited about this place as everyone seems to love it, but to be honest, it kind of disappointed me. The building is amazing: an old warehouse converted into a trendy restaurant, long communal tables, open kitchen and the bar at the end. But it might be a bit too trendy and hisptery (understandable as Central Saint Martins is next door). Even the staff seemed to be 'too cool for school' and the one that served us, even though he was nice, I had the impression that he was mocking us because of our accent...Well, now onto the food. It was, as Yelp says 'A-OK'. Apparently it was still brunch time, so I ordered the Kimchi pancake with pork belly and eggs. And it was just ok and a bit overpriced. I have had better food for less money. The pork belly was mainly undercooked fat and the pancake was very fluffy.The best thing of my lunch was the coffee; pretty and tasty latte served at the right temperature.Maybe I need to be back for the legendary breakfast, but for now, that's it. Not a big fan, sorry.

dpwd3hze-wmirRjSzmNs1A.text: This is my favorite brunch location in London. Beautifully decorated, equipped with a full service coffee bar, Caravan Kings Cross is not to be missed. I had the Pork Belly with Kimchi Pancake twice and it was simply the best brunch dish I've had in both London and in New York. Not only was the meal delicious, it was reasonably priced as well! Sadly, I no longer live ten minutes away from here, but I want to go back to London just to eat this again.

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. fried duck egg, pork belly, and kimchi pancake

xyx8-2epbJv3KWatUxJDbA.text: Very good food and coffee and cute atmosphere. I came for breakfast on a Saturday morning, but arrived right at opening and was sat at the bar with no issue at all. It did get significantly more crowded approaching 11 am, though. I had eggs on toast and a cappuccino. Both very brought out in a reasonable amount of time and very tasty. Nice place for breakfast or brunch.

plDa3A9JexYonjJ06gZi2A.text: Went here for brunch and absolutely loved it! It's the closest we've found to an American-style brunch place with great coffee and food at a reasonable price. The jalepeno corn bread was amazing. They don't take reservations for brunch, so we got there right when it opened and were seated right away but it did fill up.

VqQGoxicXHSEA4SHHjAvSw.text: I love this place.I've always been a huge fan of Caravan and now that they've opened one in college, it's especially hard not to drop in for a good meal after a hard day.Their jalapeno corn bread with chipotle butter is a good midday snack or slightly heavier starter. The bread's soft and moist and the butter's flavoursome and not too spicy. They only offer pizzas for takeaway, but if you want something simpler and less tomato-y the caramelised onion & parmesan pizza bread is a good option--and just £4.50!The best thing about their small plates is that you get to try a bit of everything. They're also very balanced dishes--nice mixture of vegetables to compliment the meat/fish, and there's always a good variety of texture in each bite. The grits, smoked trout & seabass ceviche are my favourites, though the trout is quite rich after a while! The mackerel is delicious with its perfectly crispy skin and oily meat but somehow always too salty, so ask for less salt!As for desserts, you MUST try the butterscotch caramel pot with salted shortbread!! It sounds so rich and sinful, which it probably is, but not in the way you think. The caramel is actually quite bitter (in a burnt caramel kind of way) and it isn't too sweet. The shortbread is also deliberately over-salted so when eaten together, it becomes the perfect mix of sweet and salty. I just wish they'd give a bit more shortbread!The only downside to this place is that it's always crowded. There's always a queue even if it's just for weekday lunch, and on weekends it gets crazy!**Oh, and the cocktails are far too expensive to justify the tiny tiny glasses. Just go for the food.

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Top: sea bass ceviche / bottom: grit, griolles, pecorino and truffle oil
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Jalapeno corn bread with chipotle butter

NvN0bypoDQmvAj1c_B2-mA.text: A really good option if the weather is nice as they have a lot of outdoor seating in front of the restaurant.  The service was a bit slow.  I only had tea while I was there (which was fine), but the food is supposed to be good.  I would say to go for the location and al fresco seating.

WieEJJhp-mofgqPXCB3fzg.text: I like this place. I came here for a business lunch with some coworkers and a client, and we all really enjoyed it. We all got two small plates each - word to the wise: one small plate will not be enough, but two is enough for lunch - and none of us had a bad thing to say. The staff was lovely and accommodating, though the 50p charge per person for filtered tap water was a bit weird. Eh, it's only 50p each, and it's for "extra filtered water" or something. They explained it but I sort of zoned out. Regardless, I'll definitely return.

T-n9RJxE7nyA6X_djSrYMw.text: Went yesterday on a Saturday. Busy but that's good sign.Go on a sunny day and if you can bag a table outside. Great spot. Otherwise inside has a great ambience. Really great or breakfast and brunch. Original is on Exmouth Market but this place really did help start off the development of King's Cross and their booming food scene. The egg, aubergine and blood sausage was great. My friend had Pork Belly and Kimchi, which was equally good. Coffee is superb there.

TIjsVyUryTn_lQgNVVxkWQ.text: So, I'm trying to find the words to describe this meal without being disrespectful. Dang, Caravan--you a tasty brunch*!When I went for dinner over the summer, my friend and I shared a smoked trout pizza, a burrata, and an absolutely inspired watermelon and tofu salad. This watermelon dish was a glorious reminder that even with the popularity of restaurants serving simple comfort food, there still is room for chefs to prove that they are way better than us at determining what flavors go well together.Somewhat conveniently located by King's Cross, Caravan is a great pre-train breakfast spot for commuters. It's not too crowded at 8.30, and it has free wifi. My friend and I shared a sumptuous smoked salmon and softly scrambled egg on thick sourdough, as well as a sweet and savory corn fritter thang with feta cubes laced with this really vibrant green stuff. We could not finish the last few bites, even though we had already been eating for taste for the few bites prior to our limits. I hate food waste, but I also hate taking trains feeling like I'm going to throw up. Add a real filter coffee (though about a third of an American small size), and we're off to a rip-roaring start.*I actually went for dinner and breakfast, but that wouldn't have worked as well in a David Guetta feat. Akon parody. I did go to brunch at Caravan's Exmouth Market location, and that was indeed a tasty brunch.

NzkeCVXtWcDy1Xnxf14Aig.text: A cool, yummy place! My friends and came here on a Sunday morning to try their brunch. We came shortly after they opened to beat a line forming, and we were successfully seated right away. Even 20 minutes after opening though, Caravan was already getting very crowded!Caravan is in a cool location. A short walk north from St. Pancras leads you to a very nice, peaceful area with a cute little river and park vibe. Caravan itself is a huge spacious building with an industrial feel to it. The bathroom is a big part of this - AND they even have Aesop exfoliating hand wash and lotion! We were seated and got served water right away, and then we ordered our dishes - I got the Prawn and Chorizo Omelette. The food was pretty slow coming out, but all was forgiven when we saw how pretty the food was! My omelette had a huge bed of arugula and peppers on top. It was super filling and delicious! I was jealous of my friends kimchi pancake, however. I had a bite of hers and it was so yummy - especially with the pork and the sauce.The service was a bit unresponsive, as we were left pretty much alone after giving us our food. The music was also far too loud for my taste, and that mixed with a crowded restaurant made it very difficult to talk to my friends and hear the server. I would definitely sit outside next time. Another review stated that they were charged 50p for filtered tap water, but nothing like that happened to us - our water was free. Overall, great tasting food! I will try to be back in my short time left in London.

QyzniOnsbDXkW9stSLE0DA.text: I can't rave about Caravan enough! As a student at Central Saint Martins, I usually pop in for their coffees. I recently had both breakfast and dinner there and would definitely keep going back.For breakfast we had the baked eggs, with tomato, chorizo and creme fraiche with  sourdough on the side. The tomatoes were slightly sour to offset the saltiness of the chorizo, and the eggs were a good carrier for all the flavours. For dinner we had 6 small plates--the smoked trout, mackerel, char-grilled pork, chorizo and sweet potato croquettes, seabass ceviche, and roasted quail. They were all phenomenal. The mackerel was a little too salty, but I feel like that's an anomaly. It sounds like a lot of meat but each dish came with a slightly small (but nicely so) portion of vegetables (you can see the fully descriptions of the dishes on their website). We also had the caramel butterscotch pots with shortbread. The caramel had a mousse-like texture and wasn't too sweet and tasted strongly of burnt sugar (in a good way), and the shortbread's deliberately saltier so they can be eaten together. The atmosphere is casual and unpretentious, with lots of people dining after work. The interiors are very rustic but still polished and put together. You can tell there's a lot of attention to detail with the hand-stamped paper table cloths. Our bill (for 3) came up to £70 without drinks.Highly highly recommended and I can't wait to go back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. grits and tofu
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. make real
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. fried duck egg

6gk4TR46TxHEWgqnqi25GA.text: If you fancy an overpriced turmeric salad with a generous helping of human hair then this is the place for you. Otherwise I'd suggest you make the 3 meter trek to Dishoom next door or better yet, purchase a hairless ready meal from Waitrose for half the price.

dQXHDXFANAubcSgXVPkS0w.text: We came here for brunch on the weekend, and did our best to get here as close to opening time (10am) as we could since we heard it gets crowded! We both got the caravan fry: eggs, field mushrooms, slow roast tomatoes, and bacon on grain toast. Also got an order of the apple and sage sausage. The food was delicious and cooked well, so of course there were no leftovers on my plate. It's a generous portion so you definitely won't go hungry afterwards. Get here early or else you'll be waiting!

lVa-WgTL0QJ0zvf5CvV-PQ.text: First off, Caravan is more like a 3.5/5 stars in my book. I quite like the place - the space has that cool, warehouse conversion feel we're all going crazy over nowadays, and it's always buzzing with people. The menu offers interesting dishes, and they roast their own beans. Also, it's in the revamped Granary Square. You couldn't get much cooler than that, right?The problem comes in the price, for the most part. I've come for brunch a couple of times and thought the food, whether it's fritters or a variation of french toast, was tasty. The dishes are aromatic and good comfort food. But it really is just that. The portions are small and the taste a little too...rustic to justify the price. I've had a marvellous hot chocolate from their Clerkenwell location, but the coffee I've had here has not blown me away enough to get that 3.5 stars to 4.I would recommend Caravan on the basis that you will get some nice food in a very trendy place, but while I don't mind paying a little extra for good, solid food, I won't be coming back too often because I always feel a bit robbed after paying for a meal. But I won't object to another hot chocolate!

GdWl-XqvKnL80ludbUWhog.text: Caravan is superb, they need to open one up in Chicago...just for me :)We enjoyed the following small plates...Brussell Sprouts and Pork dish - I'm a bit of a sprout fanMargherita Pizza - Didn't disappointAntipasto dish - UniqueThis place is split into two parts, a large restaurant and a smaller coffee bar. BOTH are enjoyable and the coffees are just as good as their food. I love the overall style of this place, I found it soothing. Caravan is definitely on my list during my next visit to London!

r2aXFfUMg5tM7P69vhcX0Q.text: - located at the Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design, near King`s Cross Station, at the piazza-like Granary Square (where children splash around in the fountains on sunny days)- inside: warehouse chic with painted brick and high, pipelined wooden ceilings; in the expansive dining room, office workers and art school hipsters sit side-by-side at pine and metal tables, arranged canteen-style in long lines; at the back, divided off by the bar, metal shelves are stacked with sacks of coffee beans, waiting to go into the giant on-site roaster- outside: nice seating area, can get very hot there (no sunshades)- reservation required; long queues; you sometimes have to wait for about an hour to get a table- service okay; took very long to get the check- the menu takes influence from many parts of the world; e.g. "Bulgar wheat, spinach & manouri pastille, green olive yoghurt"; "Chopped chicken livers, brioche, PX prunes" or "Mackerel fillet, seaweed, moromi miso, cucumber, sesame"- Burrata, caponata, basil oil (4.5 GBP) was good; rather small portionConclusion: Nice, modern-style restaurant, food "eccentric" and tasty!

sikJ3dP-1ITBTIe0WRuM8A.text: I've had enough of this place.They were queueing out the door when we were taken to our reserved table the other day.It then took 15 mins before we were asked whether we wanted a drink.And another 10 minutes for us to inform us the beers we ordered were no longer available.So, 25 minutes in I then deigned to ask for a menu. "A menu?" asked the waitress. "yes" I said. "something where we can see what's available to eat and then order".She looked confused but the menus eventually came.By the time we ordered the crowds were thinning out and by the time we finished our food it was pretty empty.The fried chicken bits were, frankly, disgusting. But the pizza was good. As usual, completely hit and miss with the food. I had put it down to teething problems but blimey, they've been going long enough now.The building is nice, the atmosphere buzzy. And that's why I continue to give two stars. The service and the food are really very patchy. They need to cut down the menu and the number of people they pack in. There are plenty of much better places around here now. Try Karpo, The Fellow, Smithy's, St Chads Place.

-z_9TIaOqG3HQfINu_SFaw.text: Great atmosphere, food was great, tasty plentiful. Service was intensive & warm. Would definitely recommend and can't wait to go back.

N-4QM8C7e2KmUmCpKKvGgQ.text: Prosecco on tap and delicious snacks at the bar. Need i say more.

PrdriOjlMoGoQ6bwJaDA3Q.text: Have had two business meetings in here, both over breakfast. It's a trendy yet sophisticated place to meet, just near St Pancras & King Cross. The staff are helpful, the food and drink hits the spot and the feel gives you just the right amount of intimacy. Reasonably priced. Next I need to go at another time of the day !

K0qfoT5jtCxR6oOtCfMFTQ.text: The food is average. However the atmosphere is unique with high ceilings in a building that use to be a train station.

Y28bF4YSu9ZMPWRkKjdeMw.text: Great service today. Everyone friendly and attentive. Food and coffee excellent. Great Sunday brunch.

n-jEDzhWlBPXvfjZEUh-ww.text: Was in London a few months ago, and a friend brought me to this awesome restaurant. Part of the new slew of urban restaurants to reach London, this restaurant serves great food in a casual atmosphere. Cute tapas style dining with cheerful staff, definitely try the deep fried duck egg with babaganoush, the grilled quail and super awesome desserts! If they're full, try the grain store next door, though chances are they're fully booked too!

o0FGGLgidu-Qe0yOzAWPsg.text: Nice brunch, ideal to begin the day when leaping of the train at St Pancras or Kingscross !

LKGnxnS1roM2326tTS9OKg.text: Caravan has a cool industrial vibe and a cool crowd to match. As much as I liked the atmosphere I did think that the blaring music was a bit much (especially at 11am). They are very proud of their coffee, as they should be. My cappuccino was delicious and by far the best part of my meal. I got baked eggs with chorizo - but honestly I couldn't taste the eggs. The chorizo was really strong and completely took over the dish. My friend order the scramble with bacon and fried oysters. It wasn't gross but it wasn't good. Maybe the chef was trying to be provocative... it came off as unnecessarily pretentious. Simple food done well would have been a better bet.

dfJyXIkGtyCLlt1be962Pg.text: Caravan Kings Cross is hard to find, after dark in the slightly bleak and deserted Granary Square. But after a hasty phone call for directions, it was a warm, buzzy and friendly atmosphere, in a very hip sort of post-industrialist warehouse, all bare brick and exposed pipes and loos that looked as if the builders had wandered off the job half way through. The food, though... was perfect. We shared a ham hock terrine with crushed peas on soda bread to start (which maybe could have done with a wodge of cream cheese to moisten it up) but the bread was rich and dense, the terrine pleasingly chunky. I wolfed down the polenta with girolles and truffle oil - it was absolutely delicious, creamy and comforting, with a huge pile of wild mushrooms and a generous slick of the oil. My friend had the butternut squash chorizo croquettes which were light and fluffy, crisply fried, with a side of saffron aoili. We shared a really good baked cauliflower dish with melted smoked cheese and crunchy breadcrumbs. Desserts were equally good: I really wanted the apricot clafoutis but it was only available for two to share and it might have been just a bit greedy of me to scarf it down on my own. Especially after the polenta. But I was more than happy with the caramel pot with salted shortbread fingers: it was like a big cup of dulce de leche, smooth, buttery sweet and very, very rich, with the slight note of salt on the biscuits to cut it through. If I could have scraped any more off the inside of the cup, I would have. My friend made short work of her ginger treacle tart, with properly crisp pastry and big chunks of ginger in the mix. The brunch menu, I was reliably informed, is 'insane': those grits make an appearance, with wild boar sausages. As long as they have that caramel pud, it all sounds unmissable.

0TM6-gmtXrLCNoNCPJu_ug.text: Cool atmosphere, small plates (perfect when you want to do family style and taste a bit of everything!), and a good cucumber martini. Oh and make sure to try the burrata!

fA-4V9VDFGdwLbQIIIDxxg.text: Love it. It has the atmosphere, warehouse-look, and people-spotting of a Brooklyn brunch spot. Food is good too.

nfB-rrei1c24ouPvAsTE7g.text: Among Americans who don't know any better, the UK has a pretty terrible reputation for food that seems to be based on the assumption that it is still 1992 (when I was 5 and lived in rural north Yorkshire -- the food was awful, even for a 5 year old).  I wish I could take the haters here.This was really near the flat I'd rented for the week, so I had the pleasure of eating here three times.  This place really hits two of my buttons: food and coffee.First with the coffee, which is what brought me here.  I am a massive 3rd wave coffee snob and this place stands up.  Certainly in the top 3 of London coffee (more reviews coming, but I hit most of the "right" coffee places.)  Easily within the company of the bests of the west coast like Stumptown.  Also, the only place in London with any natural process last week, even though it was cold brew only.  Seriously, what the heck?  Could have done with more cold brew options actually as it was hot for london.Breakfast, which I had twice here, was excellent.  The smoked salmon on toast was great.  a simple dish that lets the quality of ingredients shine though.  The fry was also good, but get it with fried or poached eggs, not scrambled.Lunch was a standout.  I tried by friend's pork belly -- a really well done and well presented dish.  I had the quail which was also good.  the true standout was the lamb ribs.  Holy crap.  An amazing sauce caramelized on ribs which were crispy and falling off the bone tender at the same time.  Goddamn, I wish this wasn't going to be 12 hours by plane away from me.Americans and other furinners.  Worth a detour, seriously.  This place would be impossible to get into in LA or SF, it is that good.Londoners:  Why are you still reading some Californian's review of something in your own city?

YWgk5VxRLACcY4AFGYI8Yw.text: Check out my blog 'The Recipe Suitcase' for the whole review:recipe-suitcase.blogspot…facebook.com/recipesuitc…Type of Place: A little hipsterish, spacious place kept in a simple though stylish way. You can sit in or outside, although for outside the waiting time is slightly more (for inside I never had to wait). Waiters are really nice and easy going, but still professional and keen to explain everything to you, such as their varying coffee offers with beans from many different places. What I also like is that you can have a look straight into the kitchen and there is also a bar at the end of the really huge hall, serving Bloody Marys and other exciting types of drinks. It is a very modern place, but I wouldn't say it is only for young people. Although, it is a bit noisy here I think I would definitely take my parents here. Another great thing, which might seem a bit weird saying, is the lovely scrub-hand-soap they have in the restrooms and the matching hand lotion. Food and Drinks: I am a huge fan of the coffee here. Pure filter coffee..strong, with a bit of milk if you want some. They are served in fancy glasses, reminding of a chemistry laboratory, and they always have new or varying sorts of coffee beans. Food is great as well - sure, it has to be, otherwise this wouldn't be my favourite place. I recommend the poached eggs with aubergine puree, similar to the Romanian vinete and soutsouki sausage..it is great! Also, the baked egg is a go-for! Order it with the chorizo (unless you're vegetarian) and you'll fall in love with it. It is served in a casserole dish; on the bottom there is some kind of tomato ratatouille, topped with an egg, which slowly bakes in the oven leaving the egg yolk liquid, Greek yoghurt and chorizo. It is really delicious, believe me!  The jalapeño corn bread with fried eggs and black beans was also very good, but still my main recommendation are the two previous dishes. In addition, all savoury dishes are served with their fresh grain bread. I haven't tried the sweet things such as the waffles, the granola or the porridge but rumours has it it is also recommendable. Granola with apple rose compote sounds very promising indeed. The pastries and cakes are lovely as well to round off your 'Caravan' experience. Price: Nothing to complain about, good price value - coffee and brunch are around 13£ with tips.

OqXoGzA3ljTVNHhKLm7O1g.text: The food and the ambience was totally let down by the service on the night I went with a friend. It took nearly an hour to take our order and then nearly another hour to get our food. By this time it was almost 11pm and I was close to eating my arm. No bread was offered or anything else. I was only able to get one drink during the wait. When we tried to speak with any of the passing wait staff, they acted as if we were being the biggest pains and kept referring to our waiter saying that he would be coming by soon. Poor guy had too many tables and too many angry customers because I think everyone was waiting for their food. Our waiter was super apologetic and explained it was because there were a few large groups. Well, the venue is huge so they should expect groups. If the kitchen can't handle it then they shouldn't take group reservations. I liked the ambience and since I know very little about that area of London (hence have few alternatives up my sleeve), I might try them again, particularly since the food was good when it finally arrived. But on this occasion I was really let down. I felt bad that I had made the reservation here for my friend's last dinner in London.

rzAKCO2pRlrf7GZzSm33Pg.text: Really delicious brunch + hip atmosphere! Loved this place. We visited on a Sunday morning & expected big brunch crowds - which we definitely found to be true. We planned our visit to arrive right as they opened doors at 10am, and when we got there, there was already a line outside. However, since we had gotten there as it opened, we got seated right away. I HIGHLY recommend getting to this restaurant as close to open as possible, as it filled up within 10 minutes of us being seated, and there was an hour wait after that. Anyways ... It was worth it! My husband got the jalepeno cornbread breakfast and loved it. It had a delicious and spicy corn salsa and a fried egg on top - so good! I got the muffin of the day, as well as the scrambled eggs on toast - really really good. The filter coffee was delicious and we are typically picky about that ;) This particular location is in a really cool spot of town! We wandered around Granary Square afterwards, where there was a cool vintage market going on. Definitely worth a visit!!

-QIRKkpRc9r_BdzhSH0vrg.text: Fantastic coffee .. My favourite espresso in London. Delicious inventive brunch items, nice space .. You may have to wait to be seated but quite often you can get a spot at the bar. I like the kimchi pancake with pork belly and duck egg .. Yum!

uTc6L3X-z0-z2hbBVYhJfQ.text: that have around 3 locations and i liked the kings cross brunch more . i went for 2 of them, thats how great the food are , really loved the duck and burrata

_lpI0maDFzuFshP1VwjHqw.text: Food is really nice just pruce is a bit high. Oats porridge is really tasty and I liked it a lot! I thought it may not be enough for me but I was actually stuffed after I finished it. Quite nice placeto meet up with friends for brunch! And I like the square in feont of the restuarant( ´  ` )

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Bloody Mary
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Cuppuccino
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Toast with two eggs

d97tZTksB8a1Y3KaLjCdQg.text: For a place to be this busy on a Monday night, it MUST be good.  And indeed it is.  Met up with a friend after work and hadn't thought we'd need to book ahead ... we started the evening in the outside area, overlooking the stunning water/light displays and building cranes of the never-ending Kings Cross redevelopment.  Staff were exceptionally nice and helpful, unfortunately slowing down later in the evening - but then they've been rushing around for hours ...The menu is a bit of a weird mix of small plates, pizzas and large plates.  The daily special of pecan pie with caramel-bacon icecream (yes, bacon!) and popcorn gives you an idea of some of the weird concoctions the chefs dream up.  Very impressed to be offered a taster of said icecream, but not convinced enough to actually order itI look forward to finding an excuse to come here again.

m8FpSRL4wJUPyVgWvrJ4-g.text: I had heard about Caravan long before I managed to sit inside. Friends had frequently spoken excitedly about how wonderful the brunches were and yet how long the queues also constantly appeared to be. I'm not usually a person who likes to queue for my brunch as I am of the belief that there are enough stellar places in London that you simply don't have to. And also that a queue isn't usually indicative of good food but a buzz with tourists. Caravan dispels all of this!I have finally sat and brunched there and I can tell you that it is worth the wait. (Well, maybe up to an hour. Anything more than that is ridiculous for anywhere.) We arrived just before it opened and were sat immediately. I would say the worst thing about this place is being forced to choose what to have. We ordered : The cooked breakfastThe pumpkin waffleThe kimchee pancakes...and a lot of coffee. All were absolutely delicious. Some even surprisingly so. I have no idea what they do to those tomatoes but I was thinking about them all day after we left. If you are lucky enough to get a table for brunch then you are in for a treat! The service was impeccable and the prices more than reasonable. Wake up early one morning and treat yourself!

y5rIHCbtJdXYT_1MmiFPGw.text: Super-dope spot!Definitely a hip, prime people-watching spot...much of that thanks to the renowned Central St. Martins art/fashion school students studying being next door.  The venue as a whole is huge, though the bar area could be larger.  Sexy industrial chic decor with decent wines- I need to check out their food, but for now it's certainly a gem in the King's Cross area.

PbETPGrxhzJvZQVBERaBtg.text: Wonderful!!!! Great choice for exciting brunch ideas!! Especially kimchi pancakes! Bulgur fattoush also wonderful! Great Bloody Mary & coffee too!!! Located right in the heart of newly renovated Kings Cross - but be prepared to wait a little - very popular indeed!

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Wonderful kimchi pancakes, fattoush & chilli jam!!!! Coffee is great!

zTtkZGmIfG6MtinJcaEblg.text: Breakfast is a big event at this place. They're taking it seriously.We wanted to sit outside but at 10.30 it was rammed and there was a table available inside, so in we went. First complaint: the music is too loud. Feel free to call me an old woman but it's Sunday morning and I'm out for breakfast - loud music is not what I signed up for.Staff are friendly enough, not very smiley but not the level of hipster cool where they act as though you are a huge inconvenience to them. I ordered a flat white which arrived quite promptly and was nice. The breakfast menu is slightly overwhelming and pretty confusing. Do I want warm coconut rice and mango chutney for breakfast? Is that a thing? Fortunately there are plenty of other options that are not, you know, that. I opted for aubergine puree with poached eggs, spicy sausage and sourdough toast. It was really tasty. Strong flavours, creamy aubergine, sausage just how I like it (salty, smoky, almost burnt) and poached eggs so perfect I might never bother eating them again. I may have reached peak poached egg in my life. Second complaint: They played Don't Stop Believin' and a number of other songs that just do not belong in a breakfast establishment. I get that this is presumably A Thing (a trendy thing) but it's really not great. I can think of a million other songs that would go so much better. Prices were steep for me but probably par for the course - so not a complaint. I would definitely come back here. It's conveniently located for non-locals and offering something a little bit special for that most important meal of the day.

photos.caption: Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Flat white - 2.60 - August 2014
Photo of Caravan Kings Cross - London, United Kingdom. Aubergine puree with poached eggs - 9.50 - August 2014

I2hKQF2u4e2CbFL0rcKEWA.text: This place is popular, really popular. We came for a Sunday brunch and were told it was almost a 2 hour wait. The other option was to hawk the bar and grab a seat when they came available. Not wanting to wait two hours we waited for a seat at the bar and after 10 mins a couple of stools became available. Waiting for a stool is pot luck, nobody is monitoring it so if someone comes in after you and grabs the next available space..... Tough luck!! The place is like a old ware house with functional tables, chairs and benches. It seats a lot of people but there are still massive ques. We ordered a couple of coffees while we checked out the menu and they were actually really good. It's a hot spot for Ausi's, which usually indicates the coffee will be half decent.The menu has a good amount of choices and I would have been happy with pretty much any of the options but opted for the jalipino cornflour bread with black beans and a fried egg. My wife went for a pumpkin waffle with fresh fruit.The food came out quickly..... Possibly a little too quick! But mine was good! Unfortunately my wife's was a bit on the salty side (salty waffles??!?!) We also had to ask for additional syrup as the amount it came with wasn't sufficient.Although the staff were very accommodating (think cool hipster sorts) there was a definite feeling of once you finished its time to leave and give up the seat.
